chapter.title: Configure a Document
chapter.para: To configure the components for a document, you set values in the pom.xml file, which is the configuration file for a document.
You can configure the following document components:

listitem.para: Table of contents and lists of figures, tables, examples, and equations. See .

section.title: Create and Customize the pom.xml File

procedure.para: Maven uses the pom.xml configuration file to assemble source components, including XML files, images, and code samples, into PDF or HTML output.
procedure.title: To create and customize the pom.xml file

step.para: If your project does not have a pom.xml file, copy a working pom.xml file, such as from Cloud Files or Cloud Servers.
Start with a working pom.xml such as the one used for cloud-files.docs.
Customize it to suit the current project:

listitem.para: artifactID: uniquely identifies a project within the group.
version: 1.0.0-SNAPSHOT should always be the first version. Later, use Maven to modify the version.
update the configuration section to identify the sourceDirectory and the material to be included.

step.para: You can see working pom.xmls in GitHub. There is one pom.xml per project; each project can include one or several books. For example, here is the pom.xml for Cloud Identity (aka Auth) 2.0; it builds two books.
Save the customized pom.xml in the file structure for the book, at the level above /src/.

section.title: Table of Contents, and Lists of Figures, Tables, Examples, and Equations
section.para: The generateToc tag in a configuration section contains a series of white-space separated word pairs, which define the generation or suppression of the table of contents and lists of figures, tables, examples, and equations.
The first word in each pair is the element name, such as appendix, article, book, chapter, section, and so on.
The second word is a comma-separated list that specifies which lists the element should display. Most elements just use toc, which generates a list of section titles.
But the entry for the book element also generates tables of figures, tables, examples, and equations.
The title tag generates a title for the list, such as Table of Contents.
Use a value of nop to turn off the table of contents and all lists for an element. You can also turn off a table of contents by removing the element from the parameter.
The following table describes the words that you use to generate or suppress the table of contents and lists:

tr.td: A title for the specified list, such as Table of Contents.
No operation. Disables the table of contents and all lists for an element. You can also disable the table of contents or a list by removing the element from the parameter.

section.para: For example, you might add the following markup to your pom.xml file:
section.programlisting: <generateToc> appendix toc,title article/appendix nop article toc,title book title,figure,table,example,equation chapter toc,title part toc,title preface nop qandadiv toc qandaset toc reference toc,title section toc set toc,title </generateToc>
section.para:
This markup generates the following items:
Appendix. Table of contents with a title.
Appendix in an article. No table of contents or lists.
Article. Table of contents with a title.
Book. List of figures, tables, examples, and equations with titles.
Chapter. Table of contents with a title.
Part. Table of contents with a title.
Preface. No table of contents or lists.
And so on.
